title: Attachment & Security
description: Understand your patterns of closeness and what makes you feel secure.

questions.text: When I feel disconnected from you, I typically...
choices: Wait and see if you notice
Try to create closeness through activity

therapeutic.rationale: How we respond to disconnection reveals attachment patterns. Reassurance-seekers actively pursue connection; waiters hope to be seen; protectors defend against hurt; activity-creators try indirect reconnection. Understanding these patterns helps partners recognize bids for connection even when they're indirect or hard to read.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different disconnection responses can perpetuate distance. The reassurance-seeker may feel their wait-and-see partner doesn't care; the protector may push away the pursuer. Name your patterns to each other.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared disconnection responses mean you'll handle distance similarly—which can help (you understand each other) or harm (no one bridges the gap). Self-awareness is key.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you feel disconnected, what do you do? Does this help reconnect you or push you further apart? What would help you reconnect more directly?

questions.text: What triggers my insecurity in relationships?
choices: Not hearing from you for too long

therapeutic.rationale: Insecurity triggers often connect to early attachment experiences. Silence-sensitives need regular contact; criticism-sensitives need acceptance; priority-sensitives need to feel chosen; conflict-sensitives need harmony. Knowing your partner's triggers helps you avoid accidentally activating their insecurity.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different triggers mean different things activate each of your insecurities. You may inadvertently trigger your partner without realizing. Name your triggers so they can be avoided or addressed.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared triggers suggest similar attachment wounds. You'll understand each other's sensitivity because you share it. Be extra careful with your shared trigger.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What triggers your insecurity in relationships? Where does this sensitivity come from? Does your partner know, and do they take care with it?

questions.text: What helps me feel most secure in our relationship?
choices: Knowing we can handle anything together

therapeutic.rationale: Security comes from different sources for different attachment styles. Verbal reassurance provides explicit confirmation; daily rituals provide predictability; physical affection provides bodily connection; joint capability provides confidence in the partnership. Knowing what makes your partner feel secure helps you actively create safety.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different security sources mean you need different things to feel safe. The verbal-reassurance person may not register daily rituals as security-building; the ritual-person may feel disconnected despite words. Provide security in your partner's way.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared security sources mean you'll naturally build safety through the same behaviors. You understand what creates security because it's what creates security for you.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes you feel most secure in your relationship? Is this happening regularly? What would increase your sense of safety?

questions.text: When I'm anxious about us, what helps most?

therapeutic.rationale: Relationship anxiety requires specific soothing for different people. Talkers need verbal processing; physical-comfort seekers need touch co-regulation; commitment-reassurance seekers need explicit statements; understanding-seekers need cognitive clarity. Providing the right soothing quickly calms attachment anxiety.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different anxiety-soothing needs mean your default response may not help your anxious partner. The talker may feel dismissed by distraction; the physical-comfort seeker may feel overwhelmed by processing. Ask: 'What would help right now?'
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared anxiety-soothing means you'll naturally calm each other in ways that work. You understand what helps because it's what helps you.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you feel anxious about your relationship, what helps you calm down? Does your partner know what to do? What happens when they get it right?

questions.text: In relationships, I'm most afraid of...

therapeutic.rationale: Core relationship fears shape attachment behavior. Abandonment-fearers anxiously maintain connection; independence-fearers avoid too much closeness; inadequacy-fearers seek constant validation; known-and-rejected fearers hide their true selves. Understanding your partner's core fear helps you avoid accidentally triggering it and actively soothe it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different core fears create different relationship needs. The abandonment-fearer needs reassurance; the independence-fearer needs space. What soothes one fear may trigger another—proceed with awareness.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared core fears suggest similar attachment wounds. You'll deeply understand each other's fear because you share it. Work together to soothe your shared vulnerability.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's your deepest fear in relationships? Where does it come from? Does your partner know about this fear and treat it with care?
